page.title: Unit 3 Overview: Why Should I Care?
page.contents:
Do you ever think about where your food comes from, or what it takes to get those vegetables you’re eating from the ground to your plate? Watch the video to learn a bit about the organization Farms To Grow and how farmers use statistics to make sound decisions for their farms.



In this unit, you will learn about how to graph two-dimensional data and create models of the data to make predictions. You’ll also use residuals to judge how good a model is and use correlation to describe how variables are related to each other. 

Building Character: Purpose 

Through their organization, Farms to Grow, Gordon Reed and Dr. Gail Myers work to promote the sustainability and history of Black farmers. They have a strong sense of purpose to make a positive contribution to the world. 

Throughout this unit, you will work on developing your purpose. Having purpose is showing a commitment to making a meaningful contribution to the world. Purpose drives you to make positive contributions in line with your own interests and strengths. And this pursuit gives your life direction and forward momentum; it motivates and guides your short-term goals and daily activities. With a strong sense of purpose, you flourish: you enjoy a more meaningful life, are healthier and more resilient to setbacks, live more energetically, and feel good about what you’ve accomplished.

Think about your current sense of purpose. How many of the following statements are true for you?

  • I look for ways to have positive effects on others’ lives.
  • I often reflect on my life goals and the kind of person I want to be.
  • When I plan out my day, I consider how my activities connect to what I want to accomplish with my life.
  • I often think about what I can offer the world, taking into account what the world needs as well as my personal strengths and interests.
  • I often think about what matters most to me and why it matters.

Don’t worry if none of these statements are true for you. Developing this trait takes time. Your first step starts today!

page.title: Unit 3 Overview: Am I Ready to Learn This?
page.contents:
Getting Ready for Unit 3 

To be ready for this unit, you need to be able to:

  • Distinguish linear patterns from nonlinear patterns based on scatter plots.
  • Identify positive and negative trends in a scatter plot.
  • Interpret slopes and y-intercepts of graphs of linear equations.

Next, you will answer some questions that will help you see how ready you are for this unit. If you need help, some mini-lessons will help you brush up on anything you need to work on.

answer.answer_text: Previous: Why Should I Care?
answer.response: $@NULL@$

answer.answer_text: Next: Question #1: Distinguish Patterns
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Question #1: Distinguish Patterns
page.contents: Which statement best describes the scatter plot?

answer.answer_text: There is a nonlinear pattern.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The points on the graph form a pattern that is curved.

answer.answer_text: There is no pattern.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The points on the graph do form a pattern that curves like a “u-shape.” The answer is there is a nonlinear pattern.

answer.answer_text: There is a decreasing linear pattern.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: While some points are decreasing, they all are not and there is not a linear pattern. The answer is there is a nonlinear pattern.

answer.answer_text: There is an increasing linear pattern.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:  While some points are increasing, they all are not increasing and the pattern is curved, not linear. The answer is there is a nonlinear pattern.

page.title: Distinguish Patterns: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Distinguish Linear Patterns from Nonlinear Patterns 

A scatter plot is a graph of numerical data with two variables. If two variables vary together in a predictable way, we say there is a statistical relationship between the two variables. 

  • When the points of the scatter plot seem to fall along a line, the scatter plot is linear.
  • Nonlinear patterns seem to follow a curve. 
  • If the scatter plot shows no pattern, it means there is no relationship between the variables.

There is a relationship.

It appears to be an increasing linear pattern. 

There is a relationship.

It appears to be nonlinear.

There is no relationship.


Try It: Distinguish Linear Patterns from Nonlinear Patterns

At a dinner party, every person shakes hands with every other person present. The scatter plot shows the number of people, x, and the number of handshakes, y.  


Is the relationship linear or nonlinear? Explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to describe the relationship:

The scatter plot shows that the number of handshakes increases as the number of people increases. The increase is not at a constant rate, so the relationship is nonlinear.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won't get this type of question wrong again!


Videos

Watch the following video to learn more about distinguishing linear patterns from nonlinear patterns based on scatter plots.

Scatter Plots Example

Watch the video to see scatter plots that show the relationship between study time, shoe size, and test score.

page.title: Distinguish Patterns: Mini-Lesson Review Check
page.contents: Which statement best describes the scatter plot?

answer.answer_text: There is an increasing linear pattern.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The points on this graph seem to increase from left to right and form a line. There is an increasing linear pattern.

answer.answer_text: There is no pattern.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The points form a linear pattern that increases from left and right. The answer is there is an increasing linear pattern.

answer.answer_text: There is a decreasing linear pattern.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The points do form a linear pattern but appear to be increasing from left to right. The answer is there is an increasing linear pattern.

answer.answer_text: There is a nonlinear pattern.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The points cluster in a way that creates a linear pattern and they also increase from left to right. The answer is there is an increasing linear pattern.

page.title: Question #2: Identify Positive and Negative Trends
page.contents:
The scatter plot shows data on weight in pounds (x) and fuel efficiency in miles per gallon (y) for 13 cars. 


Which statement best describes the data?

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a negative relationship between fuel efficiency and weight. The cars with greater weight tend to have lesser efficiency.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: As the x-values, weight of the cars, increase, the y-values, fuel efficiency, decrease. The relationship is negative.

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a negative relationship between fuel efficiency and weight. The cars with greater weight tend to have greater efficiency.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When there is a negative relationship, as one quantity increases, the other quantity decreases. The answer is there is a negative relationship between fuel efficiency and weight because the cars with greater weight tend to have lesser efficiency.

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a positive relationship between fuel efficiency and weight. The cars with greater weight tend to have lesser efficiency.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When one quantity increases as the other decreases, there is a negative relationship. The answer is there is a negative relationship between fuel efficiency and weight because the cars with greater weight tend to have lesser efficiency.

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a positive relationship between fuel efficiency and weight. The cars with greater weight tend to have greater efficiency.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:  When there is a positive relationship, as one quantity increases, the other quantity increases. The answer is there is a negative relationship between fuel efficiency and weight because the cars with greater weight tend to have lesser efficiency.

page.title: Identify Positive and Negative Trends: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Identify Positive and Negative Trends 

Scatter plots may have a strong linear trend or a weak linear trend. A strong positive trend means as one variable increases, the other variable increases, A strong negative trend means as one variable increases, the other variable decreases. A weak linear pattern means the points are more scattered.  


Try It: Identify Positive and Negative Trends 


Does the scatter plot show a positive or negative trend? Is the relationship weak or strong?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to describe the relationship:

As the x-values increase, the y-values decrease. The trend is negative. The relationship is linear, but the points are scattered, so the relationship is weak.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won't get this type of question wrong again!



Videos

Watch the following video to learn about trends in a scatter plot.

Khan Academy: More on Scatter Plots

The following video shows how to identify positive and negative trends in a scatter plot.

page.title: Identify Positive and Negative Trends: Mini-Lesson Review Check
page.contents:
The scatter plot shows the relationship between crocodiles body mass in pounds, x, and bite force in pounds, y.


Which statement best describes the relationship between body mass and bite force?

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a positive relationship between bite force and body mass. The greater the body mass, the greater the bite force tends to be.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: As the body mass of the crocodiles increases, so does the bite force. Since both quantities are increasing, there appears to be a positive relationship.

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a positive relationship between bite force and body mass. The greater the body mass, the lighter the bite force tends to be.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: There does appear to be a positive relationship, but that is because both quantities are increasing. The answer is there appears to be a positive relationship between bite force and body mass. The greater the body mass, the greater the bite force tends to be.

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a negative relationship between bite force and body mass. The greater the body mass, the greater the bite force tends to be.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When there is a negative relationship, one quantity increases while another decreases. The answer is there appears to be a positive relationship between bite force and body mass. The greater the body mass, the greater the bite force tends to be.

answer.answer_text: There appears to be a negative relationship between bite force and body mass. The greater the body mass, the lighter the bite force tends to be.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: looking at the scatter plot, as the body mass increases, so does the bite force. The answer is there appears to be a positive relationship between bite force and body mass. The greater the body mass, the greater the bite force tends to be.

page.title: Question #3: Interpret Slope and y-Intercept
page.contents:
The figure shows the graph of the equation used to convert temperature in Celsius to temperature in Fahrenheit: F = 9/5 C + 32.

F = 9/5C + 32 is used to convert temperatures, C, on the Celsius scale to temperatures, F, on the Fahrenheit scale. Identify and interpret the slope and F-intercept.

answer.answer_text: The slope is 9/5, which means that the temperature Fahrenheit (F) increases 9 degrees when the temperature Celsius (C) increases 5 degrees. The F-intercept is 32, which means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 32° on the Fahrenheit scale.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The coefficient of C is the slope and is 9/5. As the F-values increase by 9, the C values increase by 5. The line crosses the vertical axis (F) at 32 when C is 0. This means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 32° on the Fahrenheit scale.

answer.answer_text: The slope is 9/5, which means that the temperature Celsius (C) increases 9 degrees when the temperature Fahrenheit (F) increases 5 degrees. The F-intercept is 32, which means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 32° on the Fahrenheit scale.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:  Slope is the vertical change over the horizontal change. The top number in the slope represents the change in F and the bottom number represents the change in C. The answer is that the slope is 9/5, which means that the temperature Fahrenheit (F) increases 9 degrees when the temperature Celsius (C) increases 5 degrees. The F-intercept is 32, which means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 32° on the Fahrenheit scale.

answer.answer_text: The slope is 32, which means that for every 32 degrees Fahrenheit, it is 1 degree Celsius. The F-intercept is 9/5, which means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 5/9° on the Fahrenheit scale.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope is the change in F over the change in C and the F-intercept is 32. The answer is that the slope is 9/5, which means that the temperature Fahrenheit (F) increases 9 degrees when the temperature Celsius (C) increases 5 degrees. The F-intercept is 32, which means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 32° on the Fahrenheit scale.

answer.answer_text: The slope is 9/5, which means that the temperature Fahrenheit (F) increases 9 degrees when the temperature Celsius (C) increases 5 degrees. The F-intercept is -18, which means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 18° lower on the Fahrenheit scale.
answer.response:
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The F-intercept is where the line crosses the vertical axis. The answer is that the slope is 9/5, which means that the temperature Fahrenheit (F) increases 9 degrees when the temperature Celsius (C) increases 5 degrees.

The F-intercept is 32, which means that when the temperature is 0° on the Celsius scale, it is 32° on the Fahrenheit scale.

page.title: Interpret Slope and y-Intercept: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Interpret Slope and y-Intercept 

Many real-world applications are modeled by linear equations. Often, when a linear equation model uses real-world data, different letters are used for the variables, instead of using only x and y. The variable names remind us of what quantities are being measured.

The equation T = 1/4n + 40 is used to estimate the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, T, based on the number of cricket chirps, n, in one minute. The graph shows the relationship.


What do the slope and T-intercept represent?

Answer: The slope is ¼ and represents that for every 4 chirps per minute, the temperature increases by 1 degree. The T- intercept means when there are zero chirps, the temperature is 40 degrees.

Try It: Interpret Slope and y-Intercept

Loreen has a calligraphy business. The equation C = 1.8n + 35 models the relation between her weekly cost, C, in dollars and the number of wedding invitations, n, that she writes. The graph shows the relationship.




What do the slope and C-intercept represent?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to interpret the slope and C-intercept:

The slope is 1.8 and represents the cost increases by $1.80 for 1 invitation. The C-intercept means the cost for zero invitations is $35.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won't get this type of question wrong again!



Videos

Watch the following videos to learn more about interpreting slope and y-intercept of linear equations.

Khan Academy: Slope, x-Intercept, and y-Intercept Meaning in Context

Watch the following video to see how you can interpret slope, x-intercept, and y-intercept in context.



Khan Academy: Slope and Intercept Meaning in Context

Watch this video to see how you can interpret slope and intercept meaning in context.

answer.answer_text: I’m ready to re-check my understanding.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Interpret Slope and y-Intercept: Mini-Lesson Review Check
page.contents:
Sam drives a delivery van. The equation C = 0.5m + 60 models the relation between his weekly cost, C, in dollars and the number of miles, m, that he drives. The graph shows the relationship. 

Find and interpret the meaning of the slope and C-intercept.

answer.answer_text: The slope, 0.5, means that the weekly cost, C, increases by $0.50 when the number of miles driven, m, increases by 1. The C-intercept means that when the number of miles driven is 0, the weekly cost is $60.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: For every mile that Sam drives, the cost increases $0.50. The weekly cost is the C-intercept which is $60, when zero miles are driven.

answer.answer_text: The slope, 0.5, means the weekly cost, C, increases $0.50 a week. The C-intercept is 60, which means that every mile costs $60.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope is the change in C over the change in m. \(\frac{0.5}1\). Looking at the graph, the C-intercept, 60, is when the miles are 0.  The answer is the slope, 0.5, means that the weekly cost, C, increases by $0.50 when the number of miles driven, m, increases by 1. The C-intercept means that when the number of miles driven is 0, the weekly cost is $60.

answer.answer_text: The slope, 0.5, means that for every half mile, m, the cost, C, increases by 1. The C-intercept means that when the number of miles driven is 0, the weekly cost is $60.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope is the change in C over the change in m. The answer is the slope, 0.5, means that the weekly cost, C, increases by $0.50 when the number of miles driven, m, increases by 1. The C-intercept means that when the number of miles driven is 0, the weekly cost is $60.

answer.answer_text: The slope, 0.5, means that the weekly cost, C, decreases by $0.50 when the number of miles driven, m, increases by 1. The C-intercept means that when the number of miles driven is 60, the weekly cost is $0.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope is positive so the cost will increase per mile. The C-intercept is the weekly cost when the miles are 0. The answer is the slope, 0.5, means that the weekly cost, C, increases by $0.50 when the number of miles driven, m, increases by 1. The C-intercept means that when the number of miles driven is 0, the weekly cost is $60.

page.title: Unit 3 Overview: Wrap Up
page.contents:
How did you do? Take a moment to reflect on the answers you got right and wrong on the previous pages. Did you complete the mini-lesson reviews? If not, completing these resources can help you get a better understanding of these concepts:

  • Distinguish linear patterns from nonlinear patterns based on scatter plots.
  • Identify positive and negative trends in a scatter plot.
  • Interpret slopes and y-intercepts of graphs of linear equations.

If you are struggling, be sure to reach out to your teacher for additional help. Nobody is good at problems like this the first try. Keep at it and it will get easier.
